content.body: so some of this feedback about responsive images suggests we should send differnet images based on bandwidth
any ideas how to do that?
(i mean at a high level, not syntax levle)
should we just have two categories, "i am bandiwdth-constrained" and "i am willing to try for the biggest thing you have"?
"This is taking too long, please give me the rest of the image at the next lowest resolution"
yeah but what if the user then comes out of the tunnel?
what if it took a long time because the user started on wifi but the wifi router got hit by a dog?

FWIW, at <previous company> with a non-Web client we used JPEG2000 progressive images. The client would just terminate the request when it had enough pixels to display, but could always do an HTTP Range request for more later on, if e.g. the user zoomed in.

(More specifically, the client would request only the first 1k of data, and reason about how much more to request based on current conditions. This require the rendering pipeline and image cache to be fairly chatty.)

Hixie, my understanding is that the folks who've been exploring responsive images have thought through a lot of the use cases etc. You'll likely answer your questions better with some web research (unless folks here have specific URLs to such research))
and yes, I agree, figure out the high-level mechanics of it first, worry about syntax later.
some of the folks who've been exploring responsive images have sent zillions of e-mails on the topic to the whatwg list
so i'm pretty well covered in terms of research
email != research in my experience. that's part of the problem.
i mean, they did research, and e-mailed it to the list
have any sent URLs to wiki pages of research?
(which is the best way to do things in the whatwg world)

Hixie, it works best for you, because you've chosen to treat the whatwg list as your inbox / task list. In every other way, I've found email lists (including WHATWG) to be more of a support forum, and rarely useful for much else. Though to be fair WHATWG has a decent S/N.
well the help⊙wo list is a support forum by design, sure
the whatwg⊙wo list is a spec feedback list by design
having promised to reply to all e-mail goes a long way towards enforcing that, i think :-)

(still reading it all, but so far the focus has been on image dimensions and pixel density, i haven't seen much about the network bandwidth side of responsive design, either on the threads or on the web.)
that being said, good to hear that you're working on responsive images - I think it will be a significant improvement to the adaptability of the web platform.
(and it's content and belongs in markup, rather than presentational CSS)
well it belongs in both
depends on what kind of image we're talking about :-)
Hixie, I didn't read the whole discussion above, but I don't know of anyone who is using "always"
Hixie: the "origin" mode seems to be the most popular

rafaelw_: Sorry about the delay in reply. I changed my filters to put public-webapps under my WHATWG label instead of my catchall W3C label from now on so that they don't get lost among the volume of the long tail of W3C lists I subscribe to

hsivonen: I don't really like the idea of shoving four methodsWithLongNames on document
If we believe that people prefer jQuery-style APIs to legacy-DOM-style APIs then that clearly isn't going to be popular
So it will probably be wrapped in a way that reintroduces per-library magic and regexps

jgraham: Please suggest shorter names on the list.  I think it makes more sense to call a single method than to first call a factory method and then set a property on the object returned by the factory method.
Well the best API I can come up with is document.parse(string, ["auto"|"html"|"svg"|"mathml"|"xml"])
Where auto does some sort of magic, and the other options allow you to opt-out of the magic
tabatkins: would it be ok to have <template context=svg>?
why do we need "xml"? what would it do?
do we want contextless xml fragment parsing?
zcorpan: Maybe?  It's not *horrible*, but I'd prefer to avoid it if possible.
Maybe if it was an optional switch, so we could use it to switch on <template><a>...</></> stuff.
But still by default use the "first start tag" thing.
Then we can just say "conflicts resolve in favor of HTML" without guilt.
jgraham, I'm not sure about it until Ms2ger gets back to us on why he wants explicit timeouts instead of no test-wide timeouts at all.
window.getLastError?  Seriously?  Unix's errno was so amazingly successful and non-error-prone that people need to reinvent it in JS?
Oh, it only needs to work from window.onerror handlers.  That would make some sense, although the API could be improved upon.
And Ms2ger has just quite. OF course.
*quit
If you wanted to do that getLAstError thing, why wouldn't you just make it a property of the event?
What event?  This is window.onerror.
It's not an actual event handler.  :)
Oh. Well something that passes the error object to the "event" handler then
Not some global function that doesn't work in some situations
What do you mean?
window.onerror is the only thing that gets called for uncaught JS exceptions, right?
AryehGregor: it is a an actual event handler, but there's no actual event :-)
AryehGregor: I mean if you have some function f that is called in response to an exception e, e is an argument of, or a property of an argument of, f
jgraham, that would be nice, but it's not true for window.onerror, is it?
what you're suggesting is proposal #2
zcorpan: So it is
No idea why the author thinks it's less preferable
It seems obviously better to me
Although if IE uses e = this, that seems like an interesting alternative
this is window in IE9
I also liked the #2 better.
zcorpan: Oh well in that case I guess #2 is best
WDYT about #3 (just the stack in an argument)?
Seems more logical to make TC39 add the stack as a property of the event
of course they will probably reject that idea
Because they don't like the idea of functions being able to know their callstack
s/event/Error/
If everyone is doing it anyway, well, they don't have much to say then I guess :P

gsnedders: You appear to have started speaking in tounges

s/PTC/proper tail calls/
s/TCO/tail call optimization/
Required by what?
has obviously spent too much time dealing with compilers
Not that I am against TCO
jgraham: The spec, as it's trivially black-box observable (running out of stack)
Well I guess I should have got TCO, which might have given a clue for PTC
Required by which spec?
ES6
So the tl;dr summary is "ES6 will introduce tail call optimisation (which may screw with stack traces)"
Yeah.
A large part of why Java has never had TCO is the fact the spec requires stacktraces for errors, which effectively mean having a stack.
*means
Guido has the same reasoning for python (debuggability > recursion)
But doesn't relying on TCO mean that your stack must have the form (roughly) A B C [D E F]*
Or
jgraham: Any function with a PTC will not be on the stack after the tail call.
Or what?
gsnedders: It won't be on the stack, obviously
needs to pack for Lkpg though
I was just wondering if the stack that you would get in the absence of tail calls has to be regular in a way that would allow you to display something quite useful as a traceback
even when you do have tco
But I'm not sure that I'm right

ok so looking at http://kangax.github.com/es5-compat-table/non-standard/ and removing all columns except opera, ie9, ff12, sf5 and ch7-10, and removing lines where there are more "No" than "Yes", gives:

function statement , function "name" property, function "caller" property, function "arguments" property, __proto__ , __defineGetter__ , __defineSetter__ , const, RegExp "lastMatch", RegExp.$1-$9, String.prototype.substr, String.prototype.trimLeft, String.prototype.trimRight, String.prototype.anchor, String.prototype.big, String.prototype.blink, String.prototype.bold, String.prototype.link, Octal literals, error "stack"
Quite a few of those are in ES6
what's missing?
Off hand, function properties, __define{G,S}etter__ (note IE doesn't support this), Error.stack
IE doesn't support Error.stack either
what about function statement? (http://kangax.github.com/nfe/#function-statements )
Believe they're in, though no idea what the semantics are

Not everything that's been agreed to be added is in the spec yet, but http://wiki.ecmascript.org/doku.php?id=harmony:specification_drafts
Also still not agreement on __proto__ semantics
Noteably what us and JSC have impls of now are slightly different to what's in the spec, and in IMHO cleaner

I'm working on a custom tooltip implementation for jQuery UI, and were running into problems related to ARIA and removing the native tooltip. We set the title to an empty string to disable the native tooltip, but that causes problems with screenreaders. I've found this Chromium ticket, suggesting that event.preventDefault on mouseover should prevent the native tooltip: http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=42549 There's no mention of th

hey Hixie et al
so I have an example here: https://gist.github.com/2648133 and I've been reading through the parsing spec
Hi again!
and it seems like going from "end tag open state" to "tag name state" is a mistake
Intentional, I'm pretty sure
because "tag name state" can go to "before attribute name state" or "self-closing start tag state"
and the definition of an end tag doesn't allow either of those states
What do you mean by "allow"?
so it seems like there should be an "end tag name state" that is basically the same as "tag name state" but never goes to "before attribute name state" or "self-closing start tag state"
You can have end tags in attributes in the parser
Ms2ger: http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/syntax.html#end-tags
That's you mistake
your*
there can be trailing whitespace after the tag name, but no other characters
They are parse errors and ignored, but the tokenizer has to deal with them
The authoring requirements and the actual parsing have no meaningful relation to eachother
jsocol: The requirements on UAs are entirely unrelated to the requirements on authors
yeah that's not a bug, that's intentional
</foo bar baz> is treated as a single end tag
let me rephrase
for compat reasons
oh compat reasons?
I figured there was a reason
(the "bar baz" part turns into "attributes", that are then dropped)
It's a magic phrase
pretty much everything the parser does is for compat reasons :-)
Hixie says "compat reasons", everyone shuts up
jsocol: The whole parser is basically a big tangle of compat constraints
(btw you may find http://whatwg.org/html to be a better reference)
the unfortunate consequence of using the same "tag name state" is that the parser does something non-obvious for authors
(it's mostly the same text but is more likely to remain up to date)
Hixie: Unrelatedly, when one spins the event loop waiting for a condition, it is only supposed to observe the condition at the end of tasks, right?
jsocol, well, you've got an error
jgraham: it checks for the conditions continually, but queues a task when it is met
Hixie: Huh?
jsocol, there are multiple ways to fix it up
jgraham: which part of my statement was confusing?
jsocol, I'm not sure if one of the DOMs you expected is more obvious than what we had to go with
So if I have a script that temporarily causes a condition to be met, it thinks the condition has been met, even if it is never true at the end of the event loop?
Ms2ger: the "correct" way is obviously not to have the error. but either of those seems entirely more obvious, as a web developer
Then again, I've read some of the parsing algorithm...
than a missing > cutting off an entire paragraph
So, my definition of "obvious" may differ from the one used by sane peopl
e
jsocol: it's definitely not intuitive, i agree
welcoem to html :-)
heh :)
at the risk of being "that guy" it seems like two new states would allow the parser to do something much more intuitive with unfinished end tags
though there might be other analogous states needed elsewhere

Hixie: For example, if I have a document with one inline resource loading which is delaying the load event and I run a script (e.g. from DOMContentLoaded) that stops that load and starts a new load, should onload be delayed by the new load?
Or can that not happen for some reason?
jsocol, the final remark in http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2010-December/029409.html is relevant :)

(the only reason I can think that it might not be possible is if the "delay a load event" always happens in resposne to something async, so you always reach the end of the event loop with nothing blocking the load at least once)
Ms2ger: heh ;)
Ms2ger: to be fair, though, this isn't about aesthetics so much as Postel's law and trying to minimize the impact of a small error
jsocol, the HTML parser is a textbook example of how Postel's law is fundamentally broken
I don't think it's broken so much as "really hard"
Ms2ger: anyway, politically, if I bring this up on the list, it'll just get shot down? I don't want to waste my time.
Well
Hixie already shot you down, pretty much :)
Alternatively the HTML parser is a textbook example of how postel's law is necessary
jsocol: The requirements on UAs here aren't going to change
jgraham: fair enough.
thanks for all your time
In general we are *very* conservative with parser changes now that the main browsers are interoperable and the universe didn't end
